artist: Artist: Lorenzo Loli; Artist: after Giovanni Andrea Sirani
creditline: Gift of James A. Bergquist, Boston, in honor of Rachel McGarry
description: standing putto at right; child in LLC holding up a large coat of arms assisted by another putto at top center
inscription:
in plate, on the escutcheon ant upper left: ALL ILLUSTRISIMO  /  SIGNOR  /  ET PATRON  /  COLENDISIMO  /  IL SIGNOR  /  FILIPO  /  GVASTA VILANI,  /  vmilisimo & devotisi [^]mo  /  servitor Vitorio serena. DDD.

in plate, lower left: I. A. sirano. in.

in plate, lower right: L. LL. F.
text: This is the frontispiece for a series of playful images of putti etched by Lorenzo Loli after drawings by Giovanni Andrea Sirani. Sirani's surviving drawing for this etching reveals that he worked drew lines with a pen, then added extensive tonal washes and white highlighting, all of which Loli translated into the linear pattern seen in the etching. Cupid points to a dedication to "Filipo," a young member of the prominent Bolonese family of Guastavillani, also known as Filippo d'Angelo Michele Guastavillani. One wonders if the subjects of the series, putti or young angels, is a play on Filippo's middle name, Angelo. Additionally, the Guastavillani arms include a series of concentric circles that resemble a target, which may also have inspired the appearance of cupid in the prints. Perhaps the series as a whole could be read as a series of allusions to or lessons for Filippo.
title: Frontispiece to a series of prints dedicated to Filippo d'Angelo Michele Guastavillani
